awd_titl_txt: OCE-PRF Ecological consequences of seawater chemistry modification by ecosystem engineers
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded in whole or in part under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (Public Law 117-2).

This project will determine how ecosystem engineers shape communities by altering local chemistry. Ecosystem engineers modify the physical properties of a habitat often via the dense aggregation of individuals (e.g. mussel beds, kelp canopies, etc.)and can harbor extensive biodiversity compared to unmodified habitats. Such habitats can control resident communities through a variety of mechanisms including altering local chemistry. Through laboratory and field experiments, this project will compare how the altered chemical environments within diverse assemblages of habitat-forming species can shape long-and short-term community resilience to chemical stress. Results of this study will directly inform aquaculture, conservation, and restoration by revealing mechanisms available to prepare communities for more stressful oceans in the future. This project will additionally broaden participation in science by groups typically underrepresented in ecology by partnering with existing STEM recruitment programs and allocating funds to compensate participants. In collaboration with local shellfish aquaculture and community education programs, this project will also serve as the basis for education and outreach materials that are used to increase peoples’ connection to the environment while educating them on topics related to environmental stewardship and scientific research in an academia-industry-community collaboration.

Small scale alterations of seawater chemistry within biogenic habitats can be dominated by biological processes like respiration, photosynthesis, calcification, dissolution, and their combinations (e.g. macroalgal canopies vs coralline algal canopies vs mussel beds). Each of these processes has different consequences for the seawater carbonate system in that they can, for example, either decrease or increase carbon dioxide concentrations (photosynthesis and respiration, respectively) or either decrease or increase alkalinity (calcification and dissolution, respectively). These processes additionally occur against a backdrop of further perturbations to carbonate chemistry by larger scale processes like ocean acidification or riverine discharge. This project will examine the ability of different habitat-forming ecosystem engineers to ameliorate diverse chemical stresses within the habitat they create and the time scales over which that amelioration occurs.Short-term amelioration potential will be assessed by determining whether habitat preference of mobile or settling taxa differs under acute chemical stress conditions. By measuring growth rates of residents within diverse types of biogenic habitat this project will reveal amelioration potential during a resident organism’s lifetime. Lastly, the ability of these habitats to drive resident adaption to chemical stress will be determined by tracking how strains of a locally adapted clam originating from different types of habitats perform in the face of chemical stress events. Overall, this project, aims to reveal the chemical contexts under which various types of chemical modification by foundation species can either facilitate or inhibit the members of associated invertebrate communities across several time scales

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: University of Washington Friday Harbor Labs

por.por_cntn:
NSF Outcomes Report: 2126719

Ecosystem engineers, organisms that modify the physical properties of a habitat and often via the dense aggregation of individuals (e.g. mussel beds, kelp canopies, etc.), can harbor extensive biodiversity compared to unmodified habitats. Such biogenic habitats can control resident communities through a variety of mechanisms including altering local chemistry metabolic processes. This process has been explored in recent years as researchers investigate whether carbonate dioxide (CO2) removal in photosynthetic habitats can buffer resident organisms from ocean acidification (OA), the perturbation to the dissolved carbonate system (including lowered pH) resulting from increased anthropogenic CO2. However, single parameter perturbations to the carbonate system do not adequately capture the range of possible carbonate chemistry conditions that may be present in coastal zones. Rain, river outflow, and community calcification are capable of modifying alkalinity which changes the way the seawater chemistry is influenced by changes in CO2. Thus, the ability of these chemical modifications to drive community composition might change depending on ambient chemistry dynamics, ambient flow environments, or the physiology of resident organisms.

This project aimed to understand how species can interact via the modification of seawater chemistry while exploring the tight connections between marine organisms and their chemical environment. These investigations were conducted at the University of Washington’s Friday Harbor Laboratories. Over the two years of the grant, we maintained a long-term chemistry monitoring system and documented how marine invertebrate assemblages changed during natural variations in seawater chemistry and whether they chose different habitats depending on the ambient conditions. We also conducted experiments testing the capacity for acclimation to changes in seawater CO2 concentrations that would mimic long-term exposure to habitats dominated by different types of habitat formers. We conducted two large experiments testing the interactions between seawater CO2 and habitat type. In the first, we compared Mytius trossulus  performance in different habitats (mussel vs fleshy macroalgae vs coralline algae) across four CO2 concentrations. When exposed to high CO2 conditions, we observed that mussels growing in biogenic habitat focus on developing their tissue and organs rather than shell formation when compared to mussels grown without chemical modifications by habitat forming species (control treatement lacking habitat-formers). This suggests that there are additional effects of habitat forming species beyond the modification of carbonate chemistry that are important for habitat residents such as the provisioning of organic subsidies. In a second experiment testing the interactions between habitat type and CO2 we focused on substrate properties rather than metabolic processes. We measured the growth of juvenile oysters exposed to one of six CO2 levels and settled onto one of three types of substrate: limestone gravel, empty oyster shells, and live oysters. At the lowest CO2 concentrations, oysters settled on limestone had the highest growth rates while oysters settled on empty shell had the highest growth rates at intermediate CO2. Survivorship was highest on limestone and empty shell compared to those growing on live oysters. This suggests that the carbonate material can possibly buffer increased CO2 levels while competition with adult oysters may impair the growth and survival of the juveniles.

This project also had broader impacts by directly supporting the training of early career scientists. The primary postdoctoral researcher supported by the grant has transitioned to a tenure-track faculty position. The grant also supported research experiences for several student researchers from groups underrepresented in geoscience research careers. One Masters student completed their degree and is now a PhD student at a prestigious university. Four undergraduates were directly supported by the grant—one has completed their degree and is applying to PhD programs and the others will be graduating soon.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 12/29/2024
Modified by: Aaron T Ninokawa
